What is your overall assessment of this course?

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have learned so much! Ive developed a solid foundation in calculus. I know not only how to apply rules and general concepts, but more importantly, can trace the foundations of WHY they work. Even if youve taken the class in high school, theres so much to learn here in terms of why Calculus works!
Learned limits, derivatives, integration, and differential equations.
I learned the basics of calculus with the 23 content standards given
I learned the most important building blocks for calculus.
I learned a lot about group collaborative work. I worked a lot with my friends and asked them to explain concepts that were difficult for me to understand.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: James Barnes. Fluid, intelligent, flexible, witty. He makes learning fun, especially in a topic like math. The most understanding professor Ive had all semester, who also recognizes our common humanity as we struggle through a period of pain and grief.

The grading system. Other math classes at Yale need to follow suit of the incredible and innovative work Professor Barnes is spearheading. He has curated a system that rewards and encourages learning, without penalizing students for taking time to learn and not doing well and high  stress environments. 

Weaknesses: Re-mastery sometimes comes late, meeting we have to retain how to do some of the more specific logistical things a month or so after. Having more readily available, and regular re-quizzes might help with this
The grading system is quite frustrating. Your mastery in a certain subject is only determined by two questions that barely cover the entirety of the topic.
I LOVE THE MASTERY-BASED SYSTEM. I learn better in math when its more low-stakes and this grading was the best in regards to learning.

Strengths is the understanding and the personality of the professor, James Barnes, for me. Also love the mastery based system as it gives you multiple chances to learn the material and show that you actually are learning. 

Weakness: I would have liked problems on the PSETs to have been similar to what we go over in class. It was very frustrating to not feel adequately prepared for the PSETs from lecture. Especially when it came to word problems (not talking about rate questions).

Strengths: PROFESSOR JAMES!! He was absolutely incredible, made himself available via office hours or email. The patience of the professor really made everyone feel comfortable participating in class. I also appreciated the mastery-based grading and format of the class. It was very effective in knowing what we understood and what we needed extra help with.
Weaknesses: Canvas quizzes did not allow for partial credit and the timing was difficult.

A strength was that the professor offered office hours every day and was so willing to try to adjust to our schedules to help us. He was also really clear in what he wanted to do well in the class. In addition, he really cares about his students and cares about whether were doing ok which was so sweet. He also makes sure to listen to our questions.
This course really helps you learn the material needed for further education
I think it would've been helpful to receive direct comments on quizzes on what we did wrong and go over more pset/quiz level questions during class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having check-ins, and flexibility with attendance was really great. This allowed for us to continue to participate in the class fully, even if it meant a virtual lecture wasnt able to be attended. Office hours were also amazing

I hated the preclass videos. They were so short (like 2-4 minutes) and James is just too smart for me lol. Honestly it's like listening to a Mathematician talking to fellow mathematicians. Very hard to follow his explanations no matter how slow I made the videos lol. I would have preferred longer videos with more examples and explanations vs the short vids that seemed to be geared toward people who just like already ...get it. Especially for an online course.

I loved the daily check-ins and the compassion our professor had for the struggles of being at home and just this crazy year in general. James truly made every student feel heard and cared for in the class. This was the greatest success!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. If you were on the fence about taking a math course at Yale, this is the math class you need to start with. Such an incredible instructor, such and incredible class structure. You will not regret taking this class, even if youve taken calculus in high school. Its a great refresher and more than that, it reinforces foundations and makes you more prepared for math 115.
Well not if they can avoid it. If they must take it James Barnes is the best!
Yes, if for your requirements.

I mean if you're a pre-med you kinda don't have a choice. Honestly I won't be taking Calc 2, though I did well in the class and James made himself readily available at all times, I pretty much got myself through this class with youtube and clutch prep. I needed to find someone who didn't assume I knew small concepts not mentioned in solving the bigger concept and could dumb down their explanations of concepts -- to barney style it, as i'm just not that quick on this. So I would say if you're not strong at math, just know that you'll probably find yourself in office hours almost everyday or on youtube. But I guess that's like most classes anyways.
Yes, and try to get a section with James Barnes. He is absolutely STELLAR! If you have to take calculus for your major or for pre-med, James makes it enjoyable for sure.
Yes but only if you need it
yes, i believe this is a great course before taking Math 115.
I would recommend this course to another student. James was a great instructor and made the class as funny and unstressful as possible.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Short videos.
live virtual lectures with recording posted for every class
